sections.text:
Search for boosted keV-MeV light dark matter particles from evaporating primordial black holes at the CDEX-10 experiment
Z. H. Zhang,1 L. T. Yang ,1,* Q. Yue,1,† K. J. Kang,1 Y. J. Li,1 H. P. An,1,2 Greeshma C.,3,‡ J. P. Chang,4 Y. H. Chen,5
J. P. Cheng,1,6 W. H. Dai,1 Z. Deng,1 C. H. Fang,7 X. P. Geng,1 H. Gong,1 Q. J. Guo,8 X. Y. Guo,5 L. He,4 S. M. He,5 J. W. Hu,1 H. X. Huang,9 T. C. Huang,10 H. T. Jia,7 X. Jiang,7 S. Karmakar,3,‡ H. B. Li,3,‡ J. M. Li,1 J. Li,1 Q. Y. Li,7
R. M. J. Li,7 X. Q. Li,11 Y. L. Li,1 Y. F. Liang,1 B. Liao,6 F. K. Lin,3,‡ S. T. Lin,7 J. X. Liu,1 S. K. Liu,7 Y. D. Liu,6 Y. Liu,7 Y. Y. Liu,6 Z. Z. Liu,1 H. Ma,1 Y. C. Mao,8 Q. Y. Nie,1 J. H. Ning,5 H. Pan,4 N. C. Qi,5 J. Ren,9 X. C. Ruan,9 Z. She,1
M. K. Singh,3,12,‡ T. X. Sun,6 C. J. Tang,7 W. Y. Tang,1 Y. Tian,1 G. F. Wang,6 L. Wang,13 Q. Wang,1,2 Y. F. Wang,1
Y. X. Wang,8 H. T. Wong,3,‡ S. Y. Wu,5 Y. C. Wu,1 H. Y. Xing,7 R. Xu,1 Y. Xu,11 T. Xue,1 Y. L. Yan,7 N. Yi,1 C. X. Yu,11 H. J. Yu,4 J. F. Yue,5 M. Zeng,1 Z. Zeng,1 B. T. Zhang,1 F. S. Zhang,6 L. Zhang,7 Z. Y. Zhang,1 K. K. Zhao,7 M. G. Zhao,11
J. F. Zhou,5 Z. Y. Zhou,9 and J. J. Zhu7
(CDEX Collaboration)
1Key Laboratory of Particle and Radiation Imaging (Ministry of Education) and Department of Engineering Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084
2Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084 3Institute of Physics, Academia Sinica, Taipei 11529
4NUCTECH Company, Beijing 100084 5YaLong River Hydropower Development Company, Chengdu 610051
6College of Nuclear Science and Technology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875 7College of Physics, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065
8School of Physics, Peking University, Beijing 100871 9Department of Nuclear Physics, China Institute of Atomic Energy, Beijing 102413
10Sino-French Institute of Nuclear and Technology, Sun Yat-sen University, Zhuhai 519082 11School of Physics, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071
12Department of Physics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi 221005 13Department of Physics, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875
(Received 21 November 2022; revised 4 April 2023; accepted 3 August 2023; published 6 September 2023)
We present novel constraints on boosted light dark matter particles (denoted as “χ”) from evaporating primordial black holes (PBHs) using 205.4 kg · day data from the China Jinping Underground Laboratory’s CDEX-10 p-type point contact germanium detector with a 160 eVee analysis threshold. χ from PBHs with masses ranging from 1 × 1015 g to 7 × 1016 g are searched in this work. In the presence of PBH abundance compatible with present bounds, our result excludes the χ-nucleon elastic-scattering cross section region from 3.4 × 10−32 cm2 to 2.3 × 10−29 cm2 for χ of 1 keV to 24 MeV from PBHs with masses of 5 × 1015 g, as well as from 1.1 × 10−28 cm2 to 7.6 × 10−28 cm2 for χ of 1 keV to 0.6 MeV from PBHs with masses of 7 × 1016 g. If the χ-nucleon elastic-scattering cross section can be determined in the future, the abundance of PBHs may be severely constrained by χ evaporation. With the lower threshold (160 eVee) of the CDEX-10 experiment compared to the previously used experiments, this work allows for a better reach at soft spectra produced by heavier PBHs, which demonstrates the vast potential of such a technical route to pursue χ from larger PBHs with a low threshold.
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevD.108.052006
I. INTRODUCTION
Dark matter (DM) is an indispensable part of the standard cosmological model [1,2]. Some convincing evidence, such as galactic rotations, galaxy clusters, cosmic microwave backgrounds, and large-scale structures [3,4], supports the existence of DM. However, light dark matter particles
*Corresponding author: yanglt@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn †Corresponding author: yueq@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn ‡Participating as a member of TEXONO Collaboration.
Published by the American Physical Society under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license. Further distribution of this work must maintain attribution to the author(s) and the published article’s title, journal citation, and DOI. Funded by SCOAP3.
PHYSICAL REVIEW D 108, 052006 (2023)
2470-0010=2023=108(5)=052006(8) 052006-1 Published by the American Physical Society
(denoted as “χ”) have not been definitely found to date in various experiments, such as collider searches and direct detection (DD) experiments [5]. DD experiments, such as XENON [6], LUX-ZEPLIN [7], PandaX [8], DarkSide [9], CRESST [10], SuperCDMS [11], CoGeNT [12], and CDEX [13–23], rely on χ-nucleus (χ-N) or χ-electron scatterings through spin-independent (SI) and spindependent interactions. Collider searches provide upper bounds on the constraints of the χ-nucleon cross section for lighter χ [24]. However, in conventional searches with a traditional χ velocity distribution within the standard halo model [25,26], DD experiments rapidly lose sensitivity toward the sub-GeV (sub-MeV) range because light χ carries insufficient energy to produce nuclear (electron) recoil signals with energies higher than the detector threshold. If χ can carry higher kinetic energy through specific mechanisms [27–33], a larger parameter space can be searched for lighter χ. In recent years, it has been proposed that light χ can be upscattered or boosted to (semi)relativistic velocities through collisions with cosmic rays [23,31,32,34–39], stellar neutrinos [40,41], and diffuse supernova neutrinos [42,43]. Atmospheric collisions are also possible boosted χ sources [44–46]. Primordial black holes (PBHs) are hypothetical black holes that could be formed soon after the inflationary epoch through the gravitational collapse of density fluctuations in the early Universe [47–49]; they could also be candidates for DM [50–52]. As a result of combining quantum field theory and general relativity, PBHs emit Hawking radiation, wherein the intensity corresponds to the PBH mass [53]. Based on experimental studies of Hawking radiation, stringent constraints on PBHs with masses of MPBH ∼Oð1014–1017 gÞ have been obtained [54]. Hawking radiation comprises standard model particles such as photons, electrons, and neutrinos. χ can also be characterized as Hawking radiation [55–64]. Recently, a second potential strategy for locating boosted χ [65–67] or new particle [68–70] from PBHs has been proposed. Some research has placed constraints on PBHs using 21 cm [71–73], γ-rays [54,74–76], positron-electrons [50,77,78], neutrinos [79–81], and dwarf galaxy gas heating [82,83]. If the χ-N cross section can be determined, then χ evaporation can be used to limit the fraction of PBHs. In this study, the constraints on keV–MeV boosted χ from
evaporating PBHs are derived based on the 205.4 kg · day exposure data [23,84] from the CDEX-10 experiment, which aims at searching χ with p-type point contact germanium detectors [85] at the China Jinping Underground Laboratory (CJPL) [86], where the physics analysis threshold is 160 eVee (electron equivalent energy).

sections.heading: II. χ SPECTRA FROM EVAPORATING PBHs
sections.text:
The Hawking temperature of an evaporating PBH with mass MPBH is [87–89]
TPBH ¼ ℏc3
8πGMPBHkB ; ð1Þ
where ℏ is the reduced Planck constant, c is the speed of light in vacuum,G is the Newtonian constant of gravitation, and kB is the Boltzmann constant. PBHs with larger masses have lower Hawking temperatures. The differential number of χ per unit time evaporated by PBHs is calculated by the public code Blackhawk-v2.1 [90,91]
d2Nχ dEχdt ¼ gχ 2π ΓχðEχ ;MPBHÞ expðEχ=kBMPBHÞ þ 1 ; ð2Þ
where Eχ is the evaporated χ energy and Γχ is the graybody factor. Here, we consider the case of Dirac fermions with four degrees of freedom (gχ ¼ 4) and chargeless and spinless PBHs.

sections.heading: III. χ FLUX REACHING EARTH
sections.text:
For a monochromatic PBH mass distribution, the flux of χ reaching Earth consists of a galactic (MW) and an extragalactic (EG) component,
d2ϕχ dTχdΩ ¼ d 2ϕMWχ dTχdΩ þ d 2ϕEGχ dTχdΩ ; ð3Þ
where Tχ is the kinetic energy of χ. The MW component is
d2ϕMWχ dTχdΩ ¼ 1 4π fPBH MPBH Z dΩs 4π Z dlρNFWMW ½rðs;ϕÞ d2Nχ dTχdt ; ð4Þ
where ρNFWMW is the DM density of the Milky Way halo in the Navarro-Frenk-White DM profile [92] with a local density of ρ⊙ ¼ 0.4 GeV=cm3, rðs;ϕÞ is the galactocentric distance with the solar distance from the galactic center, s is the line-of-sight distance to the PBH, and ϕ is the angle between these two directions. fPBH is the fraction of DM composed of PBHs. For PBHs with masses ranging from 1 × 1015 g to 7 × 1016 g, the strictest constraints on PBHs are from EDGES 21 cm [71] and COMPTEL [76]. The fPBH values chosen in this work are listed in Table I and marked with black circles in Fig. 6. An analysis cutoff is applied to MPBH ¼ 7 × 1016 g since the existing experimental constraints on fPBH at larger MPBH are weak. For the EG component in Eq. (3), the effect of redshift zðtÞ on the kinetic energy should be taken into account,
d2ϕEGχ dTχdΩ ¼ fPBHρDM 4πMPBH
Z dt½1þ zðtÞ d
2Nχ dTχdt ; ð5Þ
where ρDM ¼ 2.35 × 10−30 g=cm3 is the average DM density of the Universe at the current epoch [93].
052006-2
The integral in Eq. (5) is from the time of matter-radiation equality to the age of the Universe.
Figure 1 shows the flux of χ with mass mχ ¼ 0.1 MeV reaching Earth from PBHs. PBHs with larger masses emit softer χ spectra.

sections.heading: IV. EARTH ATTENUATION
sections.text:
χ must travel through a few kilometers of rock before reaching the underground laboratory. At large scattering cross sections with a mean free path in rocks less than a few kilometers, χ will scatter with the nucleus and lose kinetic energy before reaching the detectors at underground locations. This phenomenon is called the Earth shielding effect. In this work, this process is modeled with a ballistictrajectory approximation following Refs. [31,65], which is subjected to systematic uncertainties in the numerical calculations [23,94]. We note that different results are obtained by different numerical frameworks [23,32,95].
The subject of χ attenuation by the Earth remains an open research question and will be a theme of our future efforts.
The χ flux will be changed from d 2ϕχ dT0dΩ to d 2ϕdχ dTddΩ
, where d represents the depth of rock through which incident χ passes, T0 represents the initial kinetic energy of χ, and Td represents the kinetic energy of χ reaching the detectors after traveling a distance of d. The χ flux arriving at the CJPL can be evaluated by
d2ϕdχ dTddΩ ≈ 4m2χeτ ð2mχ þ Td − TdeτÞ2 d2ϕχ dT0dΩ ; ð6Þ
with
TdðT0Þ ¼ 2mχT0
2mχeτ − T0ð1þ eτÞ ; ð7Þ
where τ ¼ d=l, d ¼ 2400 m is the rock overburden depth of the CJPL [86] and l is the interaction length given by
l ¼ X
N
nNσχN 2mNmχ ðmN þmχÞ2 −1 ; ð8Þ
where nN is the number density of element N. The density and the elemental compositions of the rocks are provided in Ref. [94]. Omitting the nuclear form factor, the χ-nucleus elastic scattering cross section σχN can be expressed with
σχN ¼ σSIχpA2N mNðmχ þmpÞ mpðmχ þmNÞ 2 ; ð9Þ
where AN is the mass number of nucleus N, σSIχp is the SI χ-nucleon elastic scattering cross section, and mN and mp are the masses of nucleus N and proton, respectively. This approximation of omitting the form factor will result in an error of less than 1% because the nuclear recoil energy spectra are softer than the ones in Ref. [94].

sections.heading: V. EXPECTED EVENT RATE IN GE DETECTORS
sections.text:
The differential event rate of the χ-germanium nucleus scattering in the detector is calculated by
dR dEr
ðErÞ¼ σχGeNGe Z
dTddΩ d2ϕdχ dTddΩ ΘðEmaxr −ErÞ Emaxr ; ð10Þ
where NGe ¼ 8.30 × 1021 g−1 is the number of germanium nuclei per gram andΘ is the Heaviside function. Emaxr is the maximum value of the recoil energy Er expressed with
Emaxr ¼ T2d þ 2mχTd Td þ ðmχ þmGeÞ2=ð2mGeÞ : ð11ÞFIG. 1. The fluxes of χ with mass mχ ¼ 0.1 MeV reachingEarth from PBHs with different masses. The fraction of DM comprising PBHs chosen in our calculation is listed in Table I.
Note: ðMPBHð1015 gÞ; fPBHÞs used by Calabrese et al. in Ref. [65] are ð0.5; 2.9 × 10−10Þ, ð1.0; 3.9 × 10−7Þ, and ð8.0; 3.7 × 10−4Þ.
052006-3
The χ-germanium nucleus elastic scattering differential cross section σχGe is given by
σχGe ¼ F2ðErÞσSIχpA2Ge mGeðmχ þmpÞ mpðmχ þmGeÞ 2 ; ð12Þ
where FðErÞ is the nuclear form factor, for which the conventional Helm form factor [96] is adopted. σSIχp is the SI χ-nucleon elastic scattering cross section. mp is the mass of the proton. AGe ¼ 72.5 is the mass number of germanium, and mGe ¼ 6.77 × 104 MeV is the mass of germanium nuclei.
In a germanium semiconductor detector, the observed total deposit energy Edet is different from the real nuclearrecoil energy Er and should be corrected by the quenching factor, Edet ¼ QnrEr. The differential event rate per deposit energy Edet can be obtained as follows:
dR dEdet ¼ dR dEr · dQnr dEr · Er þQnr −1 ; ð13Þ
where the quenching factor Qnr is determined using the Lindhard formula [97], and κ ¼ 0.16 (a typical value reported in the literature that closely matches recent measurements in the low-energy range [98]). The expected event rates in a germanium detector con-
volved with energy resolution for differentMPBHs are shown in Fig. 2(a) when mχ ¼ 0.1 MeV and σSIχp ¼ 10−29 cm2. PBHs with larger masses have softer expected energy spectra. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the expected event rate decreases at Edet ¼ 0.16 keVee, whereas the χ spectrum becomes softer as the PBH mass increases when MPBH ≳ 8 × 1015 g. The search for χ from PBHs with larger masses is more sensitive to the threshold. Figure 3 shows the expected event rates for boosted χ
from evaporating PBHs at the specified parameters (MPBH, σSIχp, B). As MPBH becomes larger, the expected spectrum becomes significantly softer. This means that low-threshold detectors can perform well in the search for χ from PBHs with larger masses.
052006-4

sections.heading: VI. EXCLUSION RESULT AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Data analysis for this work is based on a 205.4 kg · day dataset from CDEX-10. At the subkeVee energy range relevant to this analysis, background events are dominated by the Compton scattering of high-energy gamma rays and internal radioactivity from long-lived cosmogenic isotopes. Figure 3 shows the measured spectrum after subtracting the contributions from the L- and M-shell x-ray peaks derived from the corresponding K-shell x-ray intensities. Following our previous WIMP, dark photon, and χ-electron scattering analysis [18,84,99], a minimum-χ2 analysis is applied to the residual spectrum in the range of 0.16–2.16 keVee:
χ2ðMPBH; fPBH; mχ ; σSIχpÞ
¼ X i ½ni − B − SiðMPBH; fPBH; mχ ; σSIχpÞ 2 Δ2i ; ð14Þ
where ni and Δi denote the measured data and standard deviation with statistical and systematic components at the ith energy bin, respectively; Si denotes the predicted event rate; and B denotes the assumed flat-background contribution from the Compton scattering of high-energy gamma rays. Figure 4 shows the 90% confidence level (CL) exclusion regions (mχ , σSIχp) for MPBH ¼ 0.5, 1, 2, 3 and 7 × 1016 g, derived by the Feldman-Cousins unified approach with Δχ2 ¼ 1.64 [100]. The constraints from the Migdal effect analysis of CDEX-10 data [94] and cosmology [101–104],
CRESST ν-cleus 2017 surface run [105–107], and EDELWEISS-Surface [108] are shown for comparison. For visual clarity, the constraints from phenomenological interpretations of the XENON-1T data [65], obtained for different values of MPBH ¼ ð0.5; 1.0; 8.0Þ × 1015 g, are omitted from the figure. As Fig. 4 shows, both the upper and lower lines of the
exclusion regions for χ with masses below 0.1 MeVare flat. We search the exclusion regions for MPBH from 1 × 1015 g to 7 × 1016 g choosing mχ ¼ 0.1 MeV as a benchmark value for our analysis. The results are shown in Fig. 5. The constraints from phenomenological interpretations by Calabrese et al. of the XENON-1T data [65] for MPBH ¼ 8 × 1015 g are also plotted. Adoption of the latest fPBH values in Table I would give rise to weaker constraints as indicated by the red arrows, such that this work significantly extends the excluded parameter space. The next generation of the CDEX experiment, CDEX-
50, is currently under construction. A 50 kg germanium detector array will be run in a low-radioactive environment, and the radioactive background will be further reduced to ∼0.01 cpkkd in the sub-keV region [99]. As shown by the purple dashed line in Fig. 5, the lower constraints on σSIχp from 50 kg · year data of CDEX-50 will be improved by up
052006-5
to approximately three orders of magnitude compared to those from CDEX-10. At the same time, χ from PBHs with a broader mass range can be effectively searched.
In other words, if the Earth shielding effect can be omitted; as fPBH decreases, σSIχp decreases qualitatively. We fix σSIχp ¼ 10−29, 10−30 and 10−31 cm2 and then search for fPBH with mχ ¼ 0.1 MeV. Figure 6 shows the upper bounds with 90% CL on fPBH, obtained for different σSIχp. According to the projection results (thin dotted dashed lines in Fig. 6), CDEX-50 can be well placed to search for χ from PBHs with a mass of MPBH ≳ 2 × 1016 g. Some strong existing bounds from extragalactic γ-ray background (EGR) [75], EDGES 21 cm [71], Voyager-1 [77], and COMPTEL [76] observations are superimposed. The constraints from phenomenological interpretations by Calabrese et al. of the XENON-1T data [65] are also shown by dashed lines for comparison. Finally, there is the degeneracy of σSIχp and fPBH to consider. Following the determination of one of σSIχp and fPBH in the future measure, the other one can be known. For example, if PBHs exist and fPBH is accurately measured in the observation of Hawking radiation, such as γ-rays and neutrinos, accurate constraints on σSIχp can be derived. As the spectrum becomes softer, the CDEX experiment has vast potential as a technical route to pursue χ from larger PBHs with a low threshold.
